search_result.title: 'Conclave' ending explained: Let's deconstruct that big twist
search_result.text:
Spoiler alert! This story includes details of the shocking twist at the end of the papal thriller "Conclave" (in theaters now), so look away if you plan to see the movie first.

"Conclave" is less a movie about the Catholic Church than it is a thrilling procedural in the vein of legendary tick-tock epics ― think "All the President's Men" about the 1972 Watergate break-in and coverup ― that were long admired by its director, Edward Berger.

But "Conclave" differs in onesignificant way: Its shocking ending, which echoes the 2016 Robert Harris thriller on which it's based. For anyone who's a fan of the 1992 crime thriller "The Crying Game," the discovery toward the end of the movie left moviegoers gasping, at least at one festival screening several weeks back.

Join our Watch Party! Sign up to receive USA TODAY's movie and TV recommendations right in your inbox.

Despite the out-of-left-field ending of "Conclave," Berger says the big reveal is not meant to be the movie's centerpiece.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

"You certainly don’t want to spoil things for people, but whether or not that (ending) is a secret is not that important," he tells USA TODAY. "The movie doesn’t hinge on that reveal, because every character has their twists and surprises."

How does the plot set up the ending of 'Conclave'?

In the movie and the book, the 200-plus College of Cardinals has gathered at the Vatican after the death of the pope in order to elect his successor. The process is called a conclave, and is steeped in ritual and tradition.

As the voting begins inside the solemn Sistine Chapel, a number of high-profile cardinals are vying to be the new leader of the world's 1.4 billion Catholics, some making cases for themselves quite stridently, including Cardinal Tedesco (Sergio Castellitto) and Cardinal Adeyemi (Lucian Msamati). One cardinal who does not want the post is Cardinal Lawrence (Ralph Fiennes), dean of the College of Cardinals, despite encouragement by Cardinal Bellini (Stanley Tucci).

Who is Cardinal Benitez in 'Conclave'?

The wild card who ultimately upends the conclave is the mysterious and contemplative Cardinal Benitez (Carlos Diehz), who arrives late to the proceedings. Although he appears to hail from Latin America, Benitez explains to his fellow cardinals that he has been posted, apparently by the pope himself, to a variety of far-flung and usually dangerous place. Most recently he has been ministering to Catholics under siege in Afghanistan.

Benitez repeatedly votes for Lawrence, who shares his growing anger at this gesture given his own questions about faith and desire to perhaps even leave the church. But Benitez persists, explaining that Lawrence has the virtues necessary to lead the faithful, unlike some of their fellow cardinals who seem to want the job for its power and status.

Why does Cardinal Lawrence investigate Cardinal Benitez in 'Conclave'?

Cardinal Benitez comes under the scrutiny of Cardinal Lawrence, who is running the conclave. Lawrence is puzzled by unearthed documents suggesting the late pope had approved Benitez's trip from Afghanistan to Switzerland for a medical procedure.

This fact jumps to the fore after a series of literal and philosophical explosions rock the cardinals, and days into the conclave they finally and overwhelmingly elect their new leader: Cardinal Benitez. Lawrence is happy about the result, but is concerned that perhaps the medical trip hints that the newly elected pope is ill and won't last long. In secret, he presses his direct reports to dig into the details of that trip.

What is the shocking ending of 'Conclave'?

If you've made it this far, and still haven't seen the movie, you clearly want to know what happens at the end of "Conclave." So be it.

Lawrence interrupts Benitez's preparations for being announced as the new pope, and demands he be told why Benitez was given a trip to Switzerland, even though he never made the journey. Lawrence thinks perhaps Benitez has a terminal illness, but instead is told the procedure would have removed his uterus. Benitez is intersex, having reproductive parts that don't fit the traditional definition of male or female.

"What are you?" Lawrence asks.

Benitez smiles and answers: "I am as God made me."

search_result.title: Ten Things You Need to Know Today: 16 February 2023 | The Week
search_result.text:
1. Search for Sturgeon successor begins

The search for a new First Minister of Scotland is underway after Nicola Sturgeon decided to stand down. The SNP leader, who made the surprise announcement after more than eight years in the job, plans to remain in office until her successor is elected. Among those tipped to run for the post are John Swinney, deputy first minister, Kate Forbes, the finance secretary and Humza Yousaf, the health secretary who has held several senior posts in government. A recent poll over the weekend suggested Forbes was a frontrunner, said The National.

If at first you don’t secede: the rise and fall of Nicola Sturgeon

2. Corbyn attacks Starmer move

Former Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has described Keir Starmer’s decision to bar him from standing for the party at the next general election, as a “flagrant attack” on democracy. In a statement posted on Twitter, Corbyn said it was up to local party members to choose their candidate, not Labour leaders. If Corbyn decides to run at the next election as an independent it would “pose an existential dilemma for Momentum, the grassroots leftwing group that emerged out of his leadership campaign”, said The Guardian.

Subscribe to The Week Escape your echo chamber. Get the facts behind the news, plus analysis from multiple perspectives. SUBSCRIBE & SAVE Sign up for The Week's Free Newsletters From our morning news briefing to a weekly Good News Newsletter, get the best of The Week delivered directly to your inbox. From our morning news briefing to a weekly Good News Newsletter, get the best of The Week delivered directly to your inbox. Sign up

Jeremy Corbyn: what happens if former Labour leader stands again?

3. France could outgun Britain

A think tank has warned that Britain could fall behind France as Nato’s leading military power in Europe. The International Institute for Strategic Studies said France has more combat aircraft, more frigates and more troops than Britain despite spending significantly less on defence. France has 203,250 personnel across its navy, air force and army compared with 150,350 in the Britain armed forces, which is set to shrink even further. President Macron has unveiled a multi-year plan to boost defence spending by a third but Rishi Sunak is “reluctant to sanction a similar increase”, said The Times.

Can the UK rely on the British Army to defend itself?

4. Ambulance callers could be diverted

Some ambulance callers will be told to go elsewhere under a new way of screening calls, reported the BBC. NHS England is asking ambulance crews to review which non-life-threatening calls can be treated elsewhere. The category will include incidents that may not need such a fast response, such as burns and severe headaches. About 40% of calls under this category will receive callbacks from a doctor, nurse or paramedic to see whether there is an alternative to sending an ambulance. Sir Julian Hartley, chief executive of NHS Providers, which represents ambulance services, called it a “welcome step”.

5. Police reveal Bulley ‘vulnerabilities’

Police have said that missing mother Nicola Bulley had “significant issues” with alcohol brought on by her ongoing struggles with the menopause. Lancashire police said the issues “caused some real challenges” for her partner and family. After previously saying Bulley had “specific vulnerabilities”, the force acknowledged it was an unusual move to divulge such personal information about a missing person, but said it wanted to explain what it meant by “vulnerabilities”. Since the 45-year-old went missing on 27 January during a riverside dog walk in St Michael’s on Wyre there has been a huge amount of speculation and intrigue into the case.

Nicola Bulley: are armchair detectives and TikTok sleuths a help or hindrance?

6. Brockovich tells Ohio residents to leave

The environmentalist Erin Brockovich has told residents of a US town where a train carrying toxic waste derailed to ignore government guidance and leave if they do not feel safe. Around 50 carriages derailed earlier this month in East Palestine, Ohio, and the chemical cargo was burned to minimise risk of an explosion. The large fire sent a vast plume of toxic smoke into the air. Speaking to Newsnation, the activist, whose campaign against a utilities giant was turned into a Julia Roberts movie, said: “I need the community to act for themselves.”

7. Sacked Russian general found dead

A Russian general killed himself a month after he was relieved from his post by Vladimir Putin, reported The Independent. Journalists in Moscow said Major General Vladimir Makarov, 72, was the main organiser in the “hunt” for those deemed an inconvenience by the Kremlin, spearheading the oppression of journalists, opposition activists and protesters. He was found with gunshot wounds to the head at his suburban home in Golikovo, northwest of Moscow, Moskovsky Komsomolets newspaper reported.

8. NYT writers attack trans coverage

The New York Times has been accused by its own writers of fuelling “bigotry and pseudoscience” against trans people. Sex and The City actress Cynthia Dixon, writer Lena Dunham and whistleblower Chelsea Manning are among the contributors to have penned a letter raising “serious concerns” about the newspaper’s coverage of transgender, non-binary and gender nonconforming people. In a statement to NPR, the paper’s spokesperson, Charlie Stadtlander, defended the coverage, saying the issues are reported “deeply and empathetically”.

9. Pompeo says Israel is not occupying

Former US secretary of state Mike Pompeo has said Israel has a biblical claim to Palestine and is therefore not occupying it. “[Israel] is not an occupying nation,” he told the One Decision podcast, adding that “as an evangelical Christian, I am convinced by my reading of the Bible that 3,000 years on now, in spite of the denial of so many, [this land] is the rightful homeland of the Jewish people”. As Donald Trump’s diplomat, Pompeo oversaw a “shift in US policy away from mediating a two-state solution and toward more openly siding with Israel”, said The Guardian.

Will deadly rise in West Bank violence prompt full-scale Palestinian uprising?

10. Waitrose tries to lure back middle-class

Waitrose will slash prices across “hundreds of grocery staples” as it “battles to win back cash-strapped middle class shoppers”, said The Daily Telegraph. The grocery chain said nearly a quarter of price cuts are worth 20% off. Fresh vegetables, meats and cheese are among the 300 Waitrose own-brand items enjoying reductions, with a 1kg bag of carrots dropping from 60p to 50p and Savoy cabbages falling from 90p to 70p. Clive Black, a retail analyst at Shore Capital, said Waitrose’s prices have been “top of the charts, at a time of clear economic hardship”.

How to save on your weekly shop

search_result.title: Sweeping changes, bold moves mark Corran's UVM
search_result.text:
Austin Danforth, and Alex Abrami

The University of Vermont turned to Bob Corran to reshape an underfunded athletic department.

Corran quickly saw why the program was in need of an overhaul.

“We had part-time assistant coaches, you had head coaches who were teaching PE classes,” said Corran, 68, who finished his time as athletic director on Thursday. “The program really was being funded at a Division III level and that led to attitude and culture where expectations were really diminished. That had to change."

On the to-do list: Scholarships, salaries, facilities, fundraising — all areas in which UVM lagged behind its conference peers.

Thirteen years later, what is the final accounting of that mandate?

• A sweeping transformation of the university’s “front porch,” as Corran called the program when he was hired in May 2003 — vastly improved coaching salaries, a 70 percent increase in scholarships and two all-purpose turf fields, including one with lights and a 2,500-seat stadium under construction.

• Funding at levels that dwarf what the department had previously seen — Vermont’s pre-Corran athletics budget was $6.5 million and will be $19 million-plus after he departs, the bulk supporting that competitive pay structure and athletic aid.

• Revised plans and hard decisions — the grand dream of a modern, multi-purpose arena hasn’t graduated from artist renderings to reality, while the move to cut the baseball and softball teams to solve a budget shortfall in 2009, making UVM four sports lighter than the 2003-04 school year, remains controversial in the community.

“You look at where the department was before he got here to where it is now. We are just in a really healthy position to be successful,” said men’s basketball coach John Becker. “I think he absolutely was the right guy at the right time for this place. … He gave it a structure and gave it a culture.”

Time for an overhaul

Former men’s basketball coach Tom Brennan was, in more ways than one, an exception to the rule when his team skyrocketed to the top of the America East Conference for three straight NCAA Tournament berths.

And yet his career arc was indicative of the UVM athletic department as a whole.

Brennan spent most of his time at UVM with a limited number of scholarships. He famously went 14-68 his first three years and had nine losing seasons in the 16 before the Catamounts claimed their first NCAA berth in 2003.

Without the serious backing of the school’s central administration, the athletic program operated under radically different circumstances for Corran’s predecessor, Rick Farnham.

“It’s like apples and oranges,” said swimming and diving coach Gerry Cournoyer, the lone head-coaching holdover from the Farnham years.

The needs weren’t limited to resources. The people within the program needed a sense of hope, Corran said, “that things are going to get better — that things can get better.

“That was really what struck me the most when I arrived,” he said. “The lack of resources in the program and as a result of that people were just looking to get by.”

The push for transformation started at the top with former UVM President Dan Fogel, provost at Louisiana State before coming to Burlington, who was adamant that athletics needed to reflect the excellence of the university.

In his first convocation address on Sept. 3, 2002, Fogel informed the campus that it had something called a “competitive metabolism” and, in the same breath, that it needed to improve. The bullish statement became the refrain for a bold vision of the future.

“With that came some greater support and we were able to do some things internally to generate more revenue so that the marketing effort became much stronger, fundraising became much stronger,” Corran said. “It was a nice combination of the institution investing more and us creating more that really allowed us to grow pretty substantially.”

Within a year of taking the reins, Corran unveiled the Victory Club as the department’s new catch-all fundraising arm.

In the past, booster-operated clubs like Friends of UVM Hockey raised money to donate to specific sports with varying results. In 2002-03, the Friends groups for the school’s three highest-profile sports — men’s hockey, men’s basketball and women’s basketball — raised a combined $67,000. Teams that didn’t have robust community support had to resort to bake sales, t-shirt sales and car washes.

“When I got here the financial restraints on the department were pretty tough,” Cournoyer said. “It just didn’t allow the non-top tier programs, teams other than hockey and basketball at that time, to have a chance to really strive.”

Where the splintered fundraising efforts usually cobbled together between $100,000 and $200,000 each year, the Victory Club has raked in an average of $750,000 per year, according to USA Today Sports’ annual college finances reporting.

“That was tough for some of those groups to buy into because it was something they’d been doing for years and in their view of the world everything was good,” Corran said.

“They don’t have that 30,000-foot view that you need from time to time, in terms of long-term, where is the program going, how do we get to where we’re going?”

The more equitable approach raised expectations and excitement across the board. The same can be said of the attempt to cover the blind spots: Upgraded locker rooms, an expanded athletic performance center (1,200 square feet to 11,000) and converting the indoor tennis courts to a turf facility for the winter months.

Salaries, scholarships on the rise

A successful four-year stint at Division III Lycoming College in Pennsylvania got Cournoyer in the door as the Catamounts’ new swimming and diving coach in 2000. His plan was to spend three or four years, then land a different D-I gig.

Given the situation, it would be hard to fault his thinking.

“When I was hired here I actually took a pay cut to come here,” Cournoyer said. “And I had more jobs here. I had to teach PE classes on top of coaching, which took time away in my day from being a quality coach. I was on a 10-month contract — and the funny thing is no coach only works 10 months.”

The effects of Corran’s head-spinning first year changed that.

First, Cournoyer was one of several coaches to get a raise and extension. Then in March 2004 he lost his men’s team, one of four programs cut along with golf and men’s and women’s tennis. In the same stroke, the UVM women’s team saw its lot improve greatly: Supplied with 0.15 scholarships in 2003-04, the squad was one of several put on track for incremental increases.

Now at 5.75 scholarships a year, Cournoyer’s squad has gone 113-73-1 since Corran arrived, compared to a 10-88 mark the decade before.

“We’re a lot more competitive now within the conference,” Cournoyer said. “I’m recruiting against schools like Michigan and we’re getting those athletes more and more. That’s a direct result of the support we’re getting for the swimming program that wasn’t there before.”

Across the department, scholarships are up 70 percent, climbing from 88 to almost 150 since Corran’s first year.

And that’s no small outlay for one of the priciest public schools in the nation, with the annual cost of attendance for out-of-state students just shy of $54,000. The scholarship price tag for the 2015-16 school year is an estimated $7.3 million, according to figures obtained in a public records request.

“Scholarships are what help you attract the best student-athletes, allow you to be competitive, and that was a major level of focus when (Corran) arrived,” said Jeff Schulman, a senior associate athletic director since 2003 and Corran’s successor.

“You can’t compare the level of support that we can now provide to our student-athletes and our coaches and staff,” Schulman said. “Our resources are completely different and he deserves a ton of credit for that.”

From the start that transformation included boosting salaries for administrators and staff, a bid to lure and retain talent.

Corran’s initial $140,000 base salary was $55,000 more than Farnham’s final year, according to reports at the time.

When basketball coach Brennan led the Catamounts to their first NCAA appearance in 2003, he did it on a $69,000 salary. The following year, Corran’s first, coaches transitioned to 12-month contracts and reaped substantial raises. Brennan’s deal improved to the then-unprecedented realm of $97,000 per year.

Since then three athletic department employees — Corran ($243,463), Becker ($225,000) and men’s hockey coach Kevin Sneddon ($241,500) — have eclipsed $200,000 in yearly earnings, according to UVM’s annual list of base pay.

Program success during Corran era

When Mike Lonergan left for George Washington following the 2010 season, few would have guessed Becker, five years removed from working as an IT manager, would be his boss’s successor.

Although he had opportunities to join Lonergan at GW or mull an offer from Colby College, Becker went all in for the UVM men’s basketball gig.

“The easier thing would have been to maybe hire someone from a bigger program or a bigger name,” said Becker, initially tapped as interim head coach.

Corran, instead, rewarded Becker — who’s spent his time repaying that faith.

Becker’s Cats have won at least 20 games and earned post-season tournament invites in each of his five seasons. They have also made the NCAA Tournament (2012) and advanced to three America East Conference title games.

Men’s hoops since Corran’s arrival has been the department’s beacon of consistency. They are 283-147 since 2003-04, good for a 65.8 winning percentage, with four tickets booked to March Madness.

The start of Corran’s run also marked the closing chapter of the program’s golden era led by Brennan, Taylor Coppenrath and T.J. Sorrentine. But Corran and his team developed a knack for usually finding the right coach to lead a UVM program.

Out of the gate, Corran was tasked with hiring four head coaches — Bill Reichelt (skiing), Sharon Dawley (women’s basketball), Kevin Sneddon (men’s hockey) and Matt Belfield (track and field).

Schulman said those were “critical hires.”

“It was very clear to me from the beginning that this was a person who was incredibly professional and had a high level of integrity,” Schulman said. “I knew that we were going to be in good hands.”

Reichelt’s ski program returned to glory in 2012 with its sixth national title, the first since 1994. Dawley and court stars Courtnay Pilypaitis and May Kotsopoulos sent the women’s hoops program to new heights with an NCAA tournament win in 2010 to conclude a strong three-year run.

And men’s soccer has posted a 52.6 winning percentage (104-91-51) with two NCAA tournaments. In the previous 10 years, the program had a 47.9 winning percentage.

“He got us organized so we could go forward as a department. He also is a quiet leader,” said men’s soccer coach Jesse Cormier, hired in 2004. “He listens and forms his opinions after hearing the details to make an informed and analytical decision.”

But not every hire panned out. Women’s soccer did not record a winning season while Corran was on campus and is onto its third coach. Field hockey has posted a 26.8 winning percentage since 2003 and women’s basketball went into a six-year funk when Dawley left.

“Like any administrator you’re going to hit a home run with some, and sometimes you’re not,” Cournoyer said. “You’re never going to hit a home run every time.

“But what Bob has done through his tenure, which I appreciated, was support his coaches. Just look at Ryan Curtis and men’s lacrosse.”

Curtis, who stepped down after a 10-year run earlier this spring, had his best season in 2016, bringing the Catamounts to the program’s first America East championship game. Curtis compiled a 48-101 overall record; along the way, the program’s scholarship allocation grew from 5.28 to 11.45 per year.

“They struggled for years, but Bob worked with Ryan, let him develop and they were a couple goals from making the NCAA tournament,” Cournoyer said. “A lot of other administrators may have just cut someone loose quick. Bob was very cautious to make those quick decisions.”

The move to Hockey East

The men’s hockey program, still reeling from the 1999 hazing scandal, was the only winless Division I team in the country. The young women’s program had a 7-63-4 record in the last two years.

But that didn’t stop Corran and UVM from reaching out to Hockey East in December 2003.

Naturally, criticism ensued.

“We heard, ‘Who do you think you are, trying to move into the best conference in the country?’” Schulman said.

The jump from ECAC to Hockey East was officially announced Jan. 8, 2004, with commissioner Joe Bertagna on hand at the news conference. The move severed a four-decade relationship with ECAC, but Corran’s foresight would be proven right, Schulman said.

“Bob was not afraid to go against the grain,” Schulman said. “It was an example of Bob being two steps ahead of everyone else.”

In the 11 years since, the men’s program has a 47.1 winning percentage. The Cats have reached three NCAA tournaments, one Frozen Four (2009), one Hockey East final and a logged pair of league semifinal appearances. They have not, however, finished higher than seventh in the regular-season standings since 2009.

By contrast, in the 10 seasons before Corran’s tenure started, the Cats compiled a 47.9 winning percentage, made three NCAA tournament appearances and lost a memorable yet controversial Frozen Four game in 1996 during the St. Louis-Perrin-Thomas golden era.

The women’s program, which welcomed a splurge of scholarships, endured two coaching changes (Dennis Miller to Tim Bothwell and Bothwell to Jim Plumer). They have compiled a 92-146-36 record and just one winning season — 18-14-4 two winters ago — in Hockey East.

“I don’t think you can argue with the success of Hockey East,” said Schulman of the league’s challenges to win consistently.

Dropping baseball, softball

After 13 years, one choice continues to loom above the rest.

Why? The signs are — literally — all around, chiding UVM to “Bring it back!”

Facing a $1.1 million budget gap, Corran announced in February 2009 a plan to cut the school’s baseball and softball programs. The move saved more than $800,000, sparing across-the-board cuts that would have negatively impacted every program. But it also inspired bad feelings that still linger today, in large part because coach Bill Currier’s baseball team had been consistently competitive — before getting an injection of scholarships — and was the rare UVM program rich with Vermont talent.

“I’ve said often: We know it wasn’t a good decision, but it was the best decision we could make at the time,” Corran said.

Corran’s department ran different scenarios to solve the shortfall before opting to shed the two programs, which supported 43 student-athletes and six staff positions between them.

Cut scholarships from every sport? Eliminate five scholarships here, three assistant coaches there? Trim resources elsewhere, put projects on the back burner?

“When we finished that (process), we said, you know, each of these where you’re pulling from here and here, pulling from different programs, what it does is it weakens everyone,” Corran said.

The piecemeal solution would’ve been more popular and palatable. It also would’ve hacked away at the department’s philosophy of building quality the previous six years.

When the athletic administration presented its “rational, logical” solution, it encountered the opposite.

“It was very emotional and I understand that,” Corran said. “I don’t think everyone really tried to understand the rationale.”

With two exceptions, the results since 2009 appear to support the decision.

Most programs held steady with prior results, based on a comparison of win-loss records, or had noteworthy milestones. Only women’s basketball and field hockey saw winning percentages dip significantly — and coaching changes have resulted for both programs.

“We would have a much more difficult time to measure up to the league, regionally, and I think competing nationally would be a hope or a dream, not a reality,” said Cormier, whose men’s soccer team reached the NCAA Tournament last year for the first time since 2007.

Any attempt to bring back baseball or softball remains a daunting challenge, one that would only be compounded by Title IX requirements.

Assuming the same number of scholarships (five) that existed when baseball was dropped, the program would require an annual budget of roughly $700,000, Schulman said. He said that would require an endowment with a principal between $14 and $15 million. It would roughly be the same for softball.

No regrets with arena progress

Whispers of arena plans started before Corran was hired. And they will continue after he leaves his post.

But what impact did Corran have on furthering UVM’s dream to build a new arena for its hockey and basketball programs?

The blueprints are covered in Corran’s fingerprints.

“There has definitely been opportunities along the way for it go in a different direction and he’s really been the driving force to keep it on the rails and keep the discussion really prominent in the minds of our entire campus and the Trustees and the community as well,” Schulman said.

The first proposal, put forth by a UVM task force in 2008, called for an 8,000-seat, $85 million arena. When that project didn’t take off, Corran and the school unveiled a toned-down version in late 2014.

The two-phase, $65 million project would keep a hockey-basketball arena on campus and repurpose Gutterson Fieldhouse into a student fitness center. But lack of fundraising — the school needs to raise $50 million through non-debt sources to get Phase 1 under way — has kept the arena as a pipe dream.

“The arena was one that we really did want to see happen and hopefully it is going to happen here in the nearer future,” Corran said.

While he has no regrets, Corran said the 2008 financial collapse factored in the arena plans initially falling apart.

“I don’t think anyone ever leaves a job like this with everything being finished.”

Potential off-site plans with South Burlington and Burlington were revealed earlier this year, but how the university proceeds isn’t a decision for Corran to make.

“(Schulman), he’s got the challenge now but there’s good things happening and promising things happening,” Corran said.

Corran arrived in Burlington and took swift action, driven to force positive change and reshape the athletic department. Those close to him say he accomplished exactly that, making what comes next the easy part.

“There’s no anxiety about it at all. It’s much more excitement,” Corran said. “People talk about it being the next chapter and it really is, doing something completely different. And I’m really looking forward to just having some time.”

Contact Austin Danforth at 651-4851 or edanforth@freepressmedia.com. Contact Alex Abrami at 660-1848 or aabrami@freepressmedia.com. Reach both reporters on Twitter at @eadanforth and @aabrami5

search_result.title: As MSU President Clif Smart exits, he reflects on his legacy and ...
search_result.text:
Clif Smart is entering his final month as the 11th president of Missouri State University, a job that he has loved. It is not one he planned to seek, initially agreeing to serve as an interim — 13 years ago — just to provide stability during a time of upheaval.

He has spent a lot of time in recent months reflecting on what he accomplished, all that he will miss and what will come next.

Smart, who was a highly successful attorney before joining Missouri State as general counsel in 2007, announced in September that the 2023-24 year would be his last, giving the MSU Board of Governors the better part of a year to find a successor.

The board unanimously chose Richard "Biff" Williams, former president of Utah Tech University, to serve as the 12th president. He is expected to move to Springfield and assume the role shortly.

Smart has been savoring his final months in the job. In May, the board gave Smart a rare Bronze Bear Award for his contributions. Mayor Ken McClure gave him a key to the city and an anonymous donor gave more than $1 million to construct a new alumni center on campus, which will be named the Clifton M. Smart III University Advancement Center.

Smart, 63, said he plans to work until his final day. He and wife Gail, who live blocks from campus, will remain in the city and spend more time giving back as community volunteers.

On May 28, Smart sat down for an "exit interview" of sorts, reflecting on his legacy and future. Here is that interview, edited only for clarity and conciseness:

Q: You were announced as the interim president — to fill a leadership vacuum during a turbulent period — on June 27, 2011. That day, what were you most apprehensive about?

"Everything happened so quickly over that weekend, leading up to that Monday the 27th announcement. The thing that I was most apprehensive about was lack of academic experience. It became essential, if I was going to accept the position that had been offered me, that we address that immediately."

The day before, Smart and longtime MSU vice president Jim Baker convinced Frank Einhellig to serve as interim provost. Not long after, "interim" was dropped from the job titles for both Smart and Einhellig.

"We talked about what that would look like and how we'd work together. And (Einhellig) agreed, and that decision, I've often said, is maybe the best decision I've ever made. Because it set us up for success. And it reassured faculty that academics was important. And there was someone they trusted, that was going to lead that piece."

Q: Reflecting on your accomplishments as president, which were the most important to you and why?

"Having our university designated as a doctoral university is clearly at the top of the list, because that ... impacts things in lots of different levels. That was important."

Smart also referenced the plan for Missouri State to leave the Missouri Valley Conference for Conference USA, where it will become a full member during the 2025-26 athletics season.

"Although there's much left to be determined, the athletic conference decision that we've been working on the last couple of years, and that we've talked about intermittently the whole time I've been here, has the potential to be really meaningful. But there's some unknowns and some risk associated with that, as well. And so we'll have to see how that plays out."

Q: Of the physical changes to the MSU campus in the past 13 years, which one is the most meaningful to you?

"The biggest thing we were able to do was get the funding to expand and renovate (the former Temple Hall) what we now call Roy Blunt Hall. That is the biggest construction project in the history of the university. And it was also a huge need, that I didn't think there was any way we would be able to tackle."

"Yes, I'm looking forward to an alumni center that has my name on it. The welcome center was important. The Glass Hall renovation was important. The health buildings were important. A new Magers Health and Wellness Center — all those things are important. But I think they all pale in comparison to putting $125 million into a state-of-the-art science facility that no one thought we could ever get done."

Q: As you prepare to leave MSU, what do you hope will never change about the campus?

"The thing that I hope never changes is the personal connections and relationships that students develop with faculty and staff members of the university. I don't think that happens everywhere — the connections, the stories, the relationships, the undergraduate research, and teaching and peer mentoring ... It's particularly important at a big university."

Over the years, Smart estimates he's taken "maybe tens of thousands" of selfies with students and alumni. Smart chronicled his experiences as president on X, formerly Twitter, and was featured in scores of mostly silly and fun university videos on Instagram.

Q: In your interactions with students and alumni, and your social media presence, what message were you trying to convey?

"When we started it, probably several things were at the root of that. For students, nobody knew who the president was and so showing that I'm a real person, that I can laugh at myself, that I'm engaged in lots of things, I think was important. People also don't know what a president does. It's been both helpful, for internal and external constituencies, to say, 'Clif is engaged in things, he is a leader in the community, he is making a difference in Jeff City, etc.'"

"Primarily, I use it to promote the university, look at all the great things that are happening here ... It's to promote the faculty, staff and students as well as what the university does for the community."

Q: Given how public you have been during your tenure, what is something people might be surprised to learn about you?

"I'm a huge mystery book reader, fan. For example, I've read every novel Agatha Christie has written. I've read all the Lord Peter Wimsey books. I'm working my way through the Nero Wolfe books written by Rex Stout. I just read for fun."

"Another fact is I love travel, we love to travel, particularly in and around the Mediterranean. And Gail and I religiously watch Rick Steves' travel show at 9 p.m. almost every night."

Q: You have described Gail, your wife of nearly 38 years, as your partner in the presidency. What is she better at than you? How has she shaped your impact?

"She is really good at connecting deeply with people. She does that better than I do. I'm reasonably good at connecting with hundreds of people casually. My favorite example of that is at an alumni event early on ... in Florida, an older man came by himself, dressed in a coat and tie. No one dresses in a coat and tie in Florida, particularly at our alumni events, and Gail spent 30 minutes talking to him to make sure he felt included, and invited and important. And she does that over and over."

"She cares deeply about things ... That led to her running a food pantry for six years, because that was really important to her. She has both a softer side and a harder edge than I do. She's very protective of me and she is not afraid to ... give me some advice of how it could have been a little better or shorter or more impactful. And I appreciate those things, although I tease her about it sometimes."

Q: With the benefit of hindsight, what would you have done differently? And what did you learn from making a mistake?

"Without using his name, I made an awful vice president-level hire, and I knew it was the wrong hire. I felt like I'd been kind of pressured into doing it and then it didn't work. And then I didn't fix it for four years ... As soon as it was fixed, and he had moved on, the whole tone of our administrative leadership meetings changed because it was just poison to have him in the room. And what I learned from that is to go with your gut, you've got to make the hires you think are right, regardless of what others think ... And if you make a mistake, just own up to it and fix it."

Q: The toughest decision you made as president?

"To reopen as a residential campus in the fall of 2020. Because we still had the pandemic going on, we didn't have a vaccine yet, we didn't have medicine that we were confident in. We didn't know if we could do it but we had to because ... thousands of our students would have 'stopped out' and never have come back. They didn't have the ability, or the support or the technology to just do online in the fall from home. Some of them didn't have a home, some of them didn't have technology, we had to come back on campus. And there are a lot of people that thought that was a bad decision."

"The result of that was we kept our enrollment, we didn't have to lay anyone off. And we showed that we could do hard things. And I was really proud of our team."

"I still get emotional four years later thinking about that, because it was a challenging time."

Q: Your contract originally ran through summer 2026. At the time you announced plans to retire you said it was due, in part, to the presence of at least one viable internal candidate. (Only one, Provost John Jasinski, was publicly named because he was a finalist.)

"We had two at the time and the board went a different direction and that is their prerogative."

Q: How did you decide it was the right time to step down? Are you still happy with the timing?

"The timing, as things have gone on this year, has proven to be completely correct. And (the presence of an internal candidate) was a factor but it wasn't the only factor. At least as big a factor was the departure, or the moving on, of other people that have been essential to our success."

Smart singled out U.S. Sen. Roy Blunt and Missouri Gov. Mike Parson, both of whom he considers a friend, as well as state Sen. Lincoln Hough.

"Blunt has retired. He was tremendously important to our success. Gov. Parson is in his last half-year ... to have a pro-education, pro-workforce development governor is so important for a public university."

"Sen. Hough, who is running for lieutenant governor, I am confident he is going to win and he's no longer going to be appropriations chair. I can't tell you how important he has been to our success."

"When you think about those three critical people rolling off, it's good for somebody else to come in because you're going to have to build relationships again, and those relationships need to be meaningful and long-term and ... I wasn't going to be around another four years or six years."

Smart and wife Gail have two sons and six grandchildren. They enjoy traveling and want to spend more time giving back to this community.

"Personally, I wanted to go out while I was healthy, when we could do other things, before everybody was banging on the door ready to push me out. It's just better to go out kind of on your own terms."

Q: The 12th president, Richard "Biff" Williams will soon step into the role. Do you plan to be available to him as an advisor or mentor or leave him to find his own way?

"I don't expect to be a mentor but I want to be available any way he wants me to be. But I put that ball in his court. I'm not going to leave him a list of stuff to do or a bunch of issues to address. He knows how to be a president. He's been a successful president. But he's got my whole team here, right? Everyone has continued on."

"I'm happy to be available and play any role that that he would like me to play but he would need to be the one to take the initiative on those kinds of engagements. I don't want to do anything to overshadow him or hinder him being successful."

Q: Post-presidency, how active will you be on social media?

"I will be significantly less engaged and, again, I don't want to do anything to overshadow the new president. I am going to be the emeritus president and so I will significantly scale back. Don't expect to ever do another video to be posted after the last one we've got in design right now. That will go out the end of June. And my Instagram career will be over."

Q: How will your community involvement change? Are there roles you haven't been able to play because of being the MSU president?

"I haven't taken on new board roles yet ... I've got almost three years left on my City Utilities term, and we're in search for a new general manager. Expect to be involved in that. Expect to continue on on the (Mercy Health Springfield Communities) board that's not directly connected to being president of the university ... Expect to continue on the United Way (of the Ozarks) board, at least for some period of time. I have talked to Dr. Williams. He wants me to continue to chair the Missouri Partnership board, which is a statewide board, and I'll do that for another year and a half."

Smart said he wants to be more involved at the University Heights Baptist Church, which he and Gail have joined, calling it "more inclusive, welcoming."

"We'll do some specific volunteer work that isn't 'leadership' work, things like Safe to Sleep, volunteering with Gail at that. It could include Ozarks Food Harvest. There are a variety of charitable kinds of faith organizations we'd like to be more involved in."

Q: Ever consider running for elected office? For mayor?

"I did think about the mayor race and decided against it. Never interested in running for partisan office so I don't have any interest in running as a Democrat or Republican for state rep. or state senate or anything else ... Did think about the mayor's race as something I might have been interested in. But it's not the same ... as it was 10 years ago when you're really running to help your community grow. Everything has become partisan, even the the nonpartisan races. I didn't really want to be in that. I'm a big supporter, big fan of Councilman Abe McGull and I would expect to support him for mayor."

Reached by phone Tuesday, McGull confirmed he is "seriously considering" a run and will announce a decision later this year.

Q: What piqued your interest about the mayoral role? Was it because of what Mayor Ken McClure has been able to do? (McClure ran for office after a long career at Missouri State, where he was a vice president).

"It really did. And I've known other mayors as well, Bob Stephens and Tom Carlson. We love Springfield ... and we want it to continue to grow and thrive. But it's a tough environment right now and I hate to say ... while I've loved this job, it has also been a tough job. And just didn't think I wanted to go from the fire into the frying pan."

Q: What are your plans for the summer and fall?

"Our biggest plan is we are hosting a Missouri State alumni cruise from Oct. 3-13 that starts in Barcelona and ends in Rome. And we've added some days on both ends of that trip."

Q: What will you miss the most?

"I'm going to miss regular engagement with my team. I really love our academic and administrative leadership team. We're friends, we do things together. We talk about everything. We plan together, we socialize together. While some of that will continue, a lot of it won't."

"I'm also going to miss the community leadership role. A lot of that goes away because it sits on the office ... being involved in community decisions and brainstorming ideas and plans."

"We'll miss engagement with the students. That was one of the things that was surprisingly fun ... Every generation thinks the next generation is not up to theirs but what I found is this next generation is amazing and students are doing incredible things. I'm going to miss that engagement and I would have never thought that when I took this job 13 years ago."

search_result.title: Savannah police chief search begins, community input as top priority
search_result.text:
The Savannah Police Department will soon be without a permanent police chief for the third time in the last decade.

The resignation of Chief Roy Minter, who joined the department in 2018, came last week and his last day is July 28. The process for finding a new chief is already underway.

Selecting Minter's successor is the responsibility of Savannah City Manager Jay Melder, but he says he won't be the only voice in the decision-making process.

In the meantime, Melder has appointed Assistant Chief Lenny Gunther to lead the department. Gunther has been with SPD since 2001, and was appointed as assistant chief under Minter.

Melder has been part of the hiring process for two police chiefs in his career, which includes stints as an assistant city manager. At his most recent previous job, in Washington D.C., the mayor made the final call, not the city manager.

Top law dogs: A look back at two decades of Savannah police chiefs

Melder said "hiring a police chief is the most important HR decision that an executive can make."

The process he's laying out for the next few months reflects that. He said vetting would be "thorough and arduous" for applicants, and he'll be fielding opinions from a broad spectrum of voices: community members and stakeholders, faith and business leaders, SPD staff and city council. All will get a say.

Melder's plan

The last three searches conducted by the City of Savannah to find Savannah’s top cop all took about seven months. Each was conducted under a different city manager.

Melder has set a more ambitious schedule, telling council his goal is to have the next police chief hired by the end of the year — five months.

He isn't going to let that schedule speed up or slow down the process. The goal is to find the best candidate, Melder said. And to do that, the first step is to contract a "gold standard police executive recruitment firm." He says the city is in the "final stages" of that.

During the last search in 2018, Minter was one of four finalists selected for the position. All finalists underwent a series of interviews and meetings with key executive city staff, two citizens advisory panels and a law enforcement panel.

Finalists also completed a formal assessment process conducted by the city's contracted search group, Developmental Associates, LLC, in which the candidates' knowledge, skills and abilities were assessed.

Then City Manager Rob Hernandez collected feedback from those who attended the interviews and meetings before making the decision to hire Minter. Melder says he's looking to expand upon that.

Melder said the process would include online surveys and focus group settings to collect public opinion on what Savannah residents would like to see from a new chief.

Public opinion is important, Melder said, especially given the spate of officer-involved shootings in recent months as well as two recent shootings near City Market, Melder says there's a lot of trust to be built, especially in the realm of racial disparity in policing.

He wants a chief that can help build that public confidence.

"We need to recognize the reasons why some of those we serve may not trust us, and work every day to build trust and confound that distrust," Melder said. "And so we need a chief who's going to be able to continue to lead critically in that effort, and make sure that our officers understand the dynamics between policing and racial justice, and how they are really a part of the solution there and the healing and community."

Police opinion

Savannah police, from rank and file officers to the command staff, will get a say as well.

Melder said he's already having conversations with the SPD brass, with plans to expand his input collection down the chain of command. He's not ruling out internal candidates for the position, noting "I think we've got some great leadership there, and some great talent."

Input from those who would actually work day-to-day under the new chief is valuable insight, as there were plenty of officers who took issue with Minter's leadership.

In April 2020, a group of 77 members of the Savannah Police Department, including the captains of all four precincts, signed a statement of workplace conflict with 22 complaints against Minter.

The undated letter, sent to the city of Savannah’s Human Resources Department, includes claims of favoritism, public embarrassment and “outright disrespect.”

More recently, a survey of 137 Savannah police officers alluded to distrust of command staff and a culture that stokes fear of retaliation by Minter.

Melder said in his discussions with SPD staffers so far, he's learned they want a leader with good communication skills, a focus on leadership and training opportunities, and someone who supports officers through career development and pay increases.

Melder will also be proposing raises for SPD officers in an attempt to help the new chief keep staffing high and turnover low — $50,000 and up starting pay.

"We want to make sure that we're gonna get a leader into the police department who our police officers want to have, and want to work hard for," Melder said. "And so they're going to have a really important role in helping shape that criteria, which ultimately, is going to shape the decision."

Melder said Minter himself has also been part of the process, but he said ultimately, the search is about the future of the department, not the past.

"We're going to be focused on the future here, and we'll get his input. Just like I've gotten input from past leaders of the department as well," Melder said. "But really, most important to me is going to be that our officers, our corporals, our lieutenants, our sergeants, those folks who are working in the department now and are looking at 20 years to go in the department, I want to make sure that they've got a leader that they're going to feel excited about continuing their career and service for."

Melder’s decision

On the job since last September, Melder is now working to fill two major public safety vacancies following the resignation of Savannah Fire Department Chief Derik Minard last month.

The city charter gives the city manager full jurisdiction over and power to appoint various positions and department heads within the organization, including the chief of police, which means Savannah City Council will not get a vote on the matter.

At his weekly press conference last week, Savannah Mayor Van Johnson listed off a few of his wishlist superlatives for the next police chief. Johnson says he’s hoping for someone with “a mixture of knowledge, skills and abilities of policing as a profession," and “someone who has equity and inclusion in their lens.”

He even loosely quoted Rudyard Kipling’s poem “If,” noting he’s looking for someone who can “walk with the crowd and keep their virtue, or walk with kings and keep the common touch.”

But above all, Johnson said he was hoping for someone who “gets Savannah.”

“They could be a great police chief, but they have to get Savannah; they have to be able to withstand Savannah,” Johnson said. “Savannah can be a hard gig.”

Previous searches

When the city took on the search for a chief in 2014, the timeline was similar. The position was advertised for two months and attracted 11 applications from 29 states. The eventual hire, Joseph Lumpkin, was one of three finalists considered for the job.

The seven-month search included an online survey to gather input on what traits the public would like the chief to have in addition to various community panels interviews and interviews by city and county managers.

Prior to Lumpkin, it took the city seven months to settle on Willie Lovett, an internal hire. Lovett had been named interim chief following the departure of Michael Berkow.

A total of 90 applicants applied for the position. A Police Department Policy Committee, which was made up of then Savannah City Manager Michael Brown, Mayor Otis Johnson, County Manager Russ Abolt and Commission Chairman Pete Liakakis settled on Lovett.

According to past new reports, the group based their decision on Lovett’s ability to achieve five goals: Improve command staff leadership; crack down on repeat offenders; put civilians in administrative positions; engage the community; and attack drugs, gangs and gun violence.

Lovett was forced to retire in 2013 due to a sexual harassment complaint filed by a department officer and was later sentenced to nearly eight years in prison for his role in a commercial gambling operation.

Will Peebles is the enterprise reporter for Savannah Morning News. He can be reached at wpeebles@gannett.com and @willpeeblessmn on Twitter.

search_result.title: The men who could succeed Vladimir Putin | The Week
search_result.text:
Throughout history, starting and then losing unprovoked wars has been a reliable way for dictators to forfeit their grip on power, either at the vengeful hands of the countries they targeted, via palace coups by disgruntled elites or occasionally even through uprisings by ordinary citizens weary of making sacrifices for a tyrant's deadly delusions. Within days of losing the Falklands Islands War to the United Kingdom in 1982, Argentina's General Leopoldo Galtieri, the leader of the embattled military junta that had launched the war to head off popular demands for new elections, resigned his office and started the process of restoring democracy. To say that things have not ended well for many individual dictators who tried to add territorial aggrandizement to domestic oppression, from Benito Mussolini to Saddam Hussein, is putting it lightly.

That stark history surely weighs heavily on Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has been Russia's increasingly brutal authoritarian leader throughout nearly the entirety of the 21st century and whose disastrous war of choice in Ukraine entered its fourth year in February, a conflict that has failed to "achieve almost any of his stated military objectives," said the Institute for the Study of War , "despite an estimated 900,000 Russians killed and wounded." While Putin's regime is currently in no danger of being overthrown by Ukrainian tanks surrounding the Kremlin, the longer the war drags on without a decisive military breakthrough, the more likely it is that Putin could be subject to removal from rivals inside Russia, or perhaps even tossed aside by the Russian people themselves, who are no strangers to revolution.

For a few weeks in early 2025, it looked like newly elected U.S. President Donald Trump was throwing Putin a lifeline, publicly dressing down Ukrainian President Volodmyr Zelenskyy in the White House, blaming the war on its Ukrainian victims and siding with Russia at the U.N. Security Council. But in March, Trump "refused to acquiesce to Putin’s top demand," which was "ending foreign military and intelligence aid to Ukraine," said the German Marshall Fund . Trump himself "appears to be rapidly losing patience with a faltering peace process that is showing few signs of progress," said The Atlantic Council , although it remains unclear if he is "prepared to turn up the pressure on Putin and increase the costs of continuing the invasion."

Subscribe to The Week Escape your echo chamber. Get the facts behind the news, plus analysis from multiple perspectives. SUBSCRIBE & SAVE Sign up for The Week's Free Newsletters From our morning news briefing to a weekly Good News Newsletter, get the best of The Week delivered directly to your inbox. From our morning news briefing to a weekly Good News Newsletter, get the best of The Week delivered directly to your inbox. Sign up

Putin's hopes that the Trump administration would quickly impose a Moscow-friendly settlement on Ukraine have so far been dashed. Meanwhile, the war grinds on, while Putin has had to rely on military reinforcements from North Korea , forging "a marriage of convenience or even a marriage of desperation," said RAND . Putin has also had to lean on Iran, inverting the longstanding patron-client relationship between Moscow and Tehran. Iran has made "substantial contributions to Russia's ground operations" as well as "delivered hundreds of short-range ballistic missiles to Russia," said the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace . Neither of these developments is a sign of strength for Putin and his regime.

The Russian economy is also starting to groan under the weight of long-term sanctions and its wartime footing. While the Russian economy has "repeatedly defied expectations" since the beginning of the Ukraine war, even seeing significant GDP growth, Putin is fighting to "manage a wartime economy" that is struggling to combat "rising inflation, sanctions pressure and record defense sector spending," said The Atlantic Council. With inflation approaching 9% and interest rates hiked to 23%, even Putin has been forced to admit "that the country’s economy is overheating," said CNBC. Russia's economy is in "an increasingly precarious state," said Reuters, despite contradictory claims from Moscow.

At 72, Putin is also entering the twilight of his life after dominating Russian politics for 25 years. A survey of more than 40 Russia experts conducted by Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty (RFE/RL) in July 2024 found that 40% believe Putin will remain in power until he dies, while 23% expect a "palace coup." Just 3% of experts believe that Putin will ever leave voluntarily. But regardless of how it happens, there are several alternatives who may someday replace Putin as president of the Russian Federation. Putin himself "constantly considers potential successors and confirmed he has a list of candidates," said the Kyiv Independent , citing an interview the Russian strongman conducted with "pro-Russian state journalist Pavel Zarubin." Putin, unfortunately, did not reveal any names on his list.

Mikhail Mishustin

Russia's 59-year-old prime minister would be a logical choice for successor, and not just because he would become the interim president should Putin step away before his term ends. Mishustin was also regarded as Putin's most likely successor by Russia experts in the RFE/RL survey. A trained economist, Mishustin spent a decade as head of the country's tax bureau before his appointment as prime minister in 2020. Mishustin has been muted about the Ukraine war, and focused largely on containing the fallout from Western sanctions placed on Russia since the February 2022 war began — but he was reportedly opposed to Putin's decision to invade. That might make him well-placed to keep the basic structures of the Russian authoritarian regime intact, while making a strategic retreat or settling on less favorable terms than Putin has been willing to countenance.

Sergei Sobyanin

Moscow's long-time mayor, Sergei Sobyanin , has long been a rumored successor and was the second most popular choice among experts in the RFE/RL poll. The 66-year-old Sobyanin was born in Russia's Tyumen region and before embarking on a political career in the Soviet Union in the 1980s, worked in a metal pipe factory. A former regional governor who also served as Deputy Prime Minister of Russia between 2008 and 2010, Sobyanin is a close Putin ally and a member of his United Russia political party. His rise to prominence was helped by his "ability to toe whatever lines Putin has set on key aspects of Russia's internal policies while staying mum on some of the tricky-to-navigate external policies," said Olga Kiyan of Russia Matters . What makes him a top-tier contender to lead Russia after Putin is his success in keeping "Russia's capital running smoothly through mass opposition protests, the disastrous Covid pandemic and now regular Ukrainian drone attacks," said the Agence France Presse .

Dmitry Medvedev

Medvedev, 59, served four years as Russia's president from 2008 to 2012 before stepping aside for Putin in what was later revealed to be a prearranged agreement. The Leningrad native and former law professor is perhaps Putin's longest-standing ally, and he accepted the subordinate role of Prime Minister from 2012 to 2020. Now the deputy chairman of the Security Council of Russia, Medvedev has struck a belligerent tone about the war in Ukraine. "This conflict will last for a very long time. For decades, probably," he recently said to Russian news agencies, per Reuters . He has also threatened a preemptive nuclear strike if Ukraine were to try to acquire its own nuclear stockpile. Questions remain, however, about whether someone who has been so subservient to Putin for so long could take or consolidate power. The Spectator 's Mark Galeotti recounted a joke purportedly making the rounds in Moscow, in which Medvedev looks for the steering wheel in a car and Putin pulls out a remote control from the passenger seat and announces he'll be the one driving.

Sergei Kiriyenko

Putin's 62-year-old first deputy chief of staff is a jack-of-all-trades who was most recently given the job of managing the sham referenda in the regions Russia seized from Ukraine in 2022. In the 1990s, Kiriyenko was known as a liberal reformer, so much so that then-President Boris Yeltsin made him the country's youngest-ever prime minister in 1998. But Kiriyenko's tenure coincided with the country's worst post-Soviet financial crisis, and he was forced to step down after four months. During his brief turn in office, Kiriyenko made the fateful decision to appoint Putin as the head of the FSB, the successor institution to the KGB. Kiriyenko is working hard "to make himself an irreplaceable cog in the wheels of power," said Carnegie Politika . As a Putin inner-circler, Kiriyenko would likely only get the top job if the succession process was managed by Putin or his allies.

Alexei Dyumin

Dyumin, 52, cut his teeth as Putin's bodyguard in the 1990s before ascending to play various roles inside the Russian state, including deputy director of the military intelligence bureau GRU, governor of Tula Oblast and now Secretary of the State Council. Dyumin was instrumental in spiriting pro-Russian Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych out of the country in 2014 after a pro-democracy uprising in Kyiv, and then served as a special forces commander in the successful operation to seize Crimea from Ukraine. Once a deputy to Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu, extensive rumors said Dyumin would take the place of his former boss, though he did not ultimately get the position. Dyumin's rise to power is emblematic of how Putin operates, identifying allies and then shuffling them from one position of authority to another inside the sprawling Russian state. This points to a "creeping process of late as the people closest to Putin," including bodyguards, "start getting appointed to key positions," said Mark Galeotti at War on the Rocks . If Putin were to step aside voluntarily, Dyumin "would be a top contender, thanks both to his long-time proximity to the Russian leader and his versatile professional experience," said the Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies .

Nikolai Patrushev

Until May 2024 , Patrushev was the secretary of Russia's Security Council. He was also a leading proponent of the idea that there is a Western conspiracy to weaken or possibly break up the Russian Federation. The 73-year-old has known Putin since they worked together in the KGB, and became a major strategist in both the 2014 and 2022 invasions of Ukraine. "His ideas form the foundations of decisions taken by Putin. He is one of the few figures Putin listens to," said Tatiana Stanovaya to The Washington Post in 2022. "Washington and London are again conniving with Nazism and fascism," Patrushev said in a March 2023 interview with Russian newspaper Rossiyskaya Gazeta . "They have no qualms about using Ukraine to set Europe or the entire world ablaze in a belief that they can get away with anything." During the war, Patrushev traveled widely, seeking to shore up Russia's diplomatic position and playing a critical role in managing the alliance with China. But after he was replaced on Russia's Security Council by Sergei Shoigu, Patrushev's star seems to have dimmed. Patrushev's 47-year-old son Dmitry , currently deputy prime minister for agriculture, is another rumored Putin successor. The younger Patrushev has "has made a dizzying career" and "regularly attends Kremlin meetings with Putin," said RFE/RL .

Other possibilities

Before his 2023 assassination, Wagner Group mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin would also have been considered a potential successor; but in Putin's Russia, it is dangerous to be seen as having too much ambition. One name that has vaulted to the top of the potential successors list is Andrei Belousov , who was named Russia's new defense minister in May 2024. An economist by training, the 66-year-old Belousov had served as first deputy prime minister from 2021 until his appointment as defense minister. Another close Putin ally, Belousov would likely carry on with most of Putin's policies both inside and outside of Russia. The change at the defense ministry likely means that Sergei Shoigu, the outgoing minister, is on the outs with Putin, particularly given the trajectory of the war he had been tasked with overseeing. Shoigu did not receive any votes in the RFE/RL survey of Putin successors despite his appointment as Secretary of the Security Council of the Russian Federation.

There is also 66-year-old Dmitry Kozak , a former deputy prime minister and now deputy Kremlin chief of staff, who reportedly worked out an agreement with Ukraine prior to the war that Putin rejected.

In the event of a full rupture of the regime itself, of course, the list of possibilities would not be limited to Putin loyalists and other Kremlin insiders. Opposition leader Alexei Navalny would have once been the most prominent politician who could seek to lead a post-Putin Russia, but he died in prison in February 2024. Putin has had some opposition leaders, like Boris Nemtsov, assassinated , while others, like tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky, live in exile.

search_result.title: Broadmoor Baptist Church: How sexual abuse response stands ...
search_result.text:
Broadmoor Baptist Church, a Madison church commended for its initial response to an abuse report in October 2022, shares findings of third-party investigation and compliance review.

Amid recent uncertainty about future of denomination-wide reforms, Broadmoor Baptist case offers window into challenges and progress of local church leadership taking initiative to address abuse.

Third-party investigative report reveals examples of inaction by former Broadmoor Baptist pastor who later served as chief executive for Mississippi Baptist Convention.

A Jackson-area megachurch’s course reversal on a history of repeatedly mishandling sexual abuse cases offers a counternarrative within the Southern Baptist Convention to examples of denial and cover-up.

Despite a third-party inquiry's findings on Broadmoor Baptist Church's former leadership mishandling an abuse case, the third-party firm commended the Madison church's current leadership for implementing accountability measures and caring for the same survivor who the church's former leadership mistreated.

That survivor reported her case to current Broadmoor leadership in October 2022, leading the church to hire third-party firm Guidepost Solutions to investigate her case and to audit the church's policies for abuse prevention and response.

But the rarity of Broadmoor’s story these past 21 months stands in contrast to what is taking place elsewhere in the nation's largest Protestant denomination.

“It’s just so upper level that some of our churches just aren’t in that universe,” said Mississippi pastor Brad Eubank, a survivor and advocate for reform in the SBC. “We just hope everybody starts at step one and works their way through.”

She came forward to tell her story: Sexual abuse survivor shares her story of grooming by youth pastor at a MS Baptist church

Broadmoor’s progress may not be replicable for everyone in the SBC, but its story offers a window into the struggle at the local level to create substantive change in the denomination. Due to the denomination’s structure anchored in autonomous churches, the future of abuse reform in the SBC will rely on local ministry leaders to own up to failures and take initiative to operate differently.

“The current leadership at Broadmoor is to be commended for their openness and willingness to address and initiate this investigation,” third-party firm Guidepost Solutions said in its report on Broadmoor. “Though this matter went unaddressed for many years … leadership acted appropriately with dedication and transparency.”

During the course of Guidepost's inquiry, the third-party firm discovered a second abuse case unrelated to the first. That latter case is now at the center of an ongoing Mississippi Bureau of Investigation inquiry.

Guidepost’s review of Broadmoor’s policies and practices evaluated the church’s child protection policy, an abuse response policy, and a special team that oversees those policies’ implementation and compliance. The assessment found some strengths, such as volunteers consistently adhering to a two-unrelated-adult supervision rule. But Guidepost also found inconsistent and often low rates of volunteers completing background checks and an abuse response training module known as Ministry Safe.

Guidepost’s recommendations for Broadmoor to bridge policy compliance gaps is already a level of sophistication that Eubank said is uncommon for most Southern Baptist churches. Many have minimal screening measures in place, a major deficiency that the SBC Abuse Reform Implementation Task Force sought to combat through its “Essentials: Sexual Abuse Prevention and Response” curriculum. The curriculum, one of the most tangible outcomes of the task force’s two years of work that ended this June, is aimed at the convention’s many small churches with limited resources and often led by bi-vocational pastors.

The 80-page curriculum includes a list of questions for applicants for staff and volunteer leadership roles, a step-by-step guide on reporting abuse to law enforcement and state officials, and considerations for pastors to care for victims who report abuse. An online version of the curriculum features videos for church leadership teams to use in training sessions.

"It’s not the end all, be all,” Eubank said. “It is simple and a very specific target because we wanted to start small and grow big.”

Healing and confession

Even more complex than policy revisions, Broadmoor realized it also had a duty to the healing process.

Both the survivor who came forward, Tracy Ashworth, and the church needed healing, leading Broadmoor leadership to engage consultants like attorney Rachael Denhollander and to hire Guidepost. Even those decisions came with some risk due to heightened criticism among some Southern Baptist factions, placing pressure on SBC leaders not to consider Guidepost to manage abuse-related projects. The criticism follows Guidepost’s work with the SBC at the national level, such as its investigation into the history of how convention leaders handled the abuse crisis.

For Broadmoor to support Ashworth’s healing, the church is paying for counseling and it offered legal backing in the event of a lawsuit from the alleged abuser, former Broadmoor youth pastor David Ingram, over a non-disclosure agreement.

“Broadmoor took this on knowing that it could be detrimental to how people view our church,” Ashworth said in a statement, which Broadmoor published with Guidepost’s report. “Instead of being fearful, they wanted to bring this darkness to the light.”

Ashworth isn’t identified by name in the Guidepost report, but she gave permission to The Clarion Ledger to use her full name.

Then, with the revelations in Guidepost’s report, Broadmoor’s current leadership apologized on behalf of the institution for the pain it has caused.

“We did not listen when listening was desperately needed, act when action was required, or hold those accountable who should have been held responsible,” Broadmoor leadership said in a statement accompanying the release of Guidepost’s report.

Guidepost zeroed in on the actions of former Broadmoor senior pastor Jim Futral, who was the first major authority figure to learn of Ingram’s alleged abuse in a conversation with Ashworth in 1988. Guidepost found Futral’s response failed to seek clarity on key details as to the nature of the abuse, allowed Ingram to remain a Broadmoor member and ministry volunteer even after Ingram was no longer on staff, and provided zero care for Ashworth.

But Guidepost’s criticism didn’t stop there and expanded to higher levels of SBC oversight. After leading Broadmoor, Futral became chief executive for the Mississippi Baptist Convention and was confronted yet again with an opportunity to hold Ingram accountable.

After reporting Ingram’s behavior to Futral in 1988, Ashworth approached Futral in 2019 in response to Ingram starting a new job as pastor of Tinsley Baptist Church. Ashworth noted a resolution the SBC adopted at its 2019 annual meeting that says a pastor accused of abuse is not qualified to serve in ministry. Despite Futral and Ashworth agreeing on the need to address Ingram’s appointment at Tinsley, Futral never acted and instead dodged Ashworth’s follow-up requests.

It was only later that Futral’s successor, Shawn Parker, who stepped into the role in late 2019 and was unaware of these conversations about Ingram, acted. Within a week of Broadmoor’s announcement in October 2022 about the abuse report involving Ingram, the Mississippi Baptist Convention notified Tinsley Baptist it was disfellowshipped from the state convention.

Ingram and Futral did not respond to The Clarion Ledger’s requests for comment.

“While autonomous churches might choose to deal with cases in a contextual manner, we pray that every church will recognize the heinous nature of sexual abuse and address such situations,” Parker said in a statement regarding the report on Broadmoor. Parker added the Mississippi Baptist Convention developed and revised its own staffing and ministry policies “to encourage protection for the vulnerable, to provide support for victims, and to assist churches if abuse should occur.”

At least two dozen other state Southern Baptist conventions have taken up similar initiatives, inspired by a recognition that state leaders can more effectively guide change at the ground level based on close relationships with local ministry leaders. Even more decisively, state convention leaders in South Carolina announced a plan last year to employ a contractor to serve as a full-time sexual abuse adviser.

Meanwhile, reform at the national level of the SBC is currently in stasis following the expiration of the SBC Abuse Reform Implementation Task Force in June. Members of that task force are helping lead a new nonprofit that still promises to launch an early version of a database of ministers accused of abuse. Many other reforms are now in the hands of the SBC Executive Committee, which is the denomination’s administrative arm, and its staff and members are expected to discuss those next steps at a meeting in September.

Liam Adams covers religion for The Tennessean. Reach him at ladams@tennessean.com or on social media @liamsadams.

search_result.text:
Plans to update the coronation of King Charles III by including a new Homage of the People have triggered anger and mockery as the big day approaches.

During the historic ceremony on Saturday 6 May, millions of viewers worldwide will be invited to “cry out and swear allegiance” to the monarch, said ITV News, marking “the first time in history” that the public will play “an active role” in a coronation.

The Homage of the People will replace the traditional Homage of Peers, in which hereditary peers would pledge allegiance to the monarch in person. But while the change seems intended to “widen access and engagement” with the ceremony, said LBC, critics claim the “tone deaf” oath “holds the people in contempt”.
